overview_of_class: In this seminar, we will reconstruct episodes in the history of collection from early modern Europe to the twentieth century, seeking to align collecting practices and the contents of collections with the epistemological and aesthetic conditions of their accumulation. We will examine a range of early modern collections - royal, princely, middle-class, artistic, scientific (medical and pharmaceutical); matrices of collecting (from studioli to gardens to stuffy crowded rooms of dried things); and private and public concerns related to such collections. Building on this, the initial focus of the seminar, we will explore the changing conditions of collection and display through the Enlightenment and into modern museology. It was Alfred Barr, Jr., of the MoMA, who instituted the "white cube" mode of gallery display. This seminar responds to recent and ever-expanding literature on the history of collections, collecting practices, and museology, and is informed by a commitment to understanding the philosophical status of sensual engagement with objects of nature and artefacts deemed works of art alike.

topic: From the Wunderkammer to the White Cube
